discussion.content: If the Patches have been slowly released how i am able to update the ciphers ?

comments.content: The patches are for the VPN software, not the ciphers. You dont patch ciphers you can just upgrade to a stronger one.

questions.question_text: A company has made it a spending priority to implement security architectures that will be resilient during an attack. Recent incidents have involved attackers leveraging latent vulnerabilities in cryptographic implementations and VPN concentrators to be able to compromise sensitive information. Patches have been slowly released for these emergent vulnerabilities, leaving weeks to months of exposed and vulnerable attack surface. Which of the following approaches would be BEST to increase enterprise resilience during similar future attacks?

choices.B: Segment remote VPN users logically from the production LAN
choices.D: Upgrade the cryptographic ciphers used on the VPN concentrators
choices.A: Implement appliances and software from diverse manufacturers
choices.C: Maximize open-source software to benefit from swifter patch releases

discussion.content:
D
Threat intelligence feeds are a main source of current threat/exploit knowledge

D
Threat intelligence feeds are a main source of current threat/exploit knowledge
answer is probably c: white papers.

Where does comptia get this stuff? The closest thing I could find to "threat data subscription" is threat intelligence subscription. A threat intel subscription looks like it might be something that updates the software. 
https://www.radware.com/products/threat-intelligence/
Maybe "threat data subscription" means "threat intelligence service?"
https://www.recordedfuture.com/threat-intelligence-vendors/
I am guessing a "threat intelligence service" is better than "software vendor threat reports" because vendor reports might only concern themselves with threats that might affect that vendor's products or services?

questions.question_text: The security administrator of a small firm wants to stay current on the latest security vulnerabilities and attack vectors being used by crime syndicates and nation- states. The information must be actionable and reliable. Which of the following would BEST meet the needs of the security administrator?

choices.A: Data-at-rest encryption misconfiguration and repeated key usage
choices.D: VM escape attacks against the customer network hypervisors
choices.C: The ability to scrape data remnants in a multitenancy environment
choices.B: Offline attacks against the cloud security broker service

discussion.content: I'm thinking it's C too just because it mentions elasticity. So I'm thinking that it's leading us to scraping data remnants. I read A and D as penetrating the customer network so it can't be those? And I agree with vorozco, B doesn't make sense.

Maybe: B. Offline attacks against the cloud security broker service?
The pentester was able to get "multiple sets of administrator credentials." Seems unlikely such information could be obtained by scraping data remnants. The information was obtained "without penetrating the customer network." 
I don't like any of the answers. But I think B may be better than C.

comments.content: This is assuming that by "credentials" they mean login credentials - i.e. login names and password. I think it unlikely that administrators would put such information where it could be scraped.
Who store unencrypted passwords? Even if there were data remnants of passwords, wouldn't those be encrypted, or hashed?
I think what makes B not a correct option is "offline." Can a CASB be reachable offline?

questions.question_text:
A security consultant is conducting a penetration test against a customer enterprise that comprises local hosts and cloud-based servers. The hosting service employs a multitenancy model with elastic provisioning to meet customer demand. The customer runs multiple virtualized servers on each provisioned cloud host.
The security consultant is able to obtain multiple sets of administrator credentials without penetrating the customer network. Which of the following is the MOST likely risk the tester exploited?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Here the engineer proposes a solution. So the test can be carried out before and after the solution is implemented and check if that is fixing the flaw.

Maybe: D. Running frequent vulnerability scans during the project?
The question specifically asks for a way to show progress during each phase of the project. This is the only option that offers a way to show such progress.

questions.question_text:
A manufacturing company's security engineer is concerned a remote actor may be able to access the ICS that is used to monitor the factory lines. The security engineer recently proposed some techniques to reduce the attack surface of the ICS to the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO). Which of the following would
BEST track the reductions to show the CISO the engineer's plan is successful during each phase?

choices.C: Performing pre- and post-implementation penetration tests
choices.A: Conducting tabletop exercises to evaluate system risk
choices.D: Running frequent vulnerability scans during the project
choices.B: Contracting a third-party auditor after the project is finished

discussion.content:
Maybe: A. The developers should require an exact version of the open-source security products, preventing the introduction of new vulnerabilities?
if libfile.3.7.lib is fully tested, and known to be good, you don't want the application to be able to compile with libfile.3.8.lib until the newer file is tested.

choices.B: The application development team should move to an Agile development approach to identify security concerns faster.
choices.D: The application should eliminate the use of open-source libraries and products to prevent known vulnerabilities from being included
choices.C: The change logs for the third-party libraries should be reviewed for security patches, which may need to be included in the release
choices.A: The developers should require an exact version of the open-source security products, preventing the introduction of new vulnerabilities.

questions.question_text: A development team releases updates to an application regularly. The application is compiled with several standard, open-source security products that require a minimum version for compatibility. During the security review portion of the development cycle, which of the following should be done to minimize possible application vulnerabilities?
